title: Intra-arterial Drug Delivery to the Ischemic Brain in Rat Middle Cerebral Artery Occlusion Model
procedures: Animal preparationExamine the rats for gross abnormalities and behavioral deficits prior to anesthesia and operation.Weigh each rat and then anesthetize in an appropriate dose of Ketamine (80 mg/kg)/Xylazine (7 mg/kg). Rats with 270-310 g are appropriate for surgery.Put the rat in a supine position on a gauze pad lying over a thermal blanket on surgery board to maintain body temperature of 37 ± 0.5 °C during the surgery. Check the rat body temperature during the surgical procedures using a rectal thermometer.Fix the forelimbs on the surgery board carefully.Cervical dissectionApply 70% alcohol on the anterior neck over the front part of the neck for sterilization and disinfection.Apply 10% lidocaine solution for local anesthesia of neck area. Besides, lidocaine avoids high activity of the vagus nerve and imbalance of sympathetic nerves that can occur during the separation of vagus nerve from carotid sheath, leading to decrease of animal survival.Place eye cream on both eyes to avoid corneal drying.Make a midline incision using scissors through the skin from the manubrium of the sternum to the area under the jaw.Divide the right and left submandibular glands under microscope guidance and dissect the gland on the side of arterial surgery (right or left) to release it from the surrounding fascia. The carotid triangle should be visible at this step. Digastrics muscle is a landmark for finding carotid triangle (Figure 2).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20191127/20191127231622_1488.jpgFigure 2. The carotid triangle and the location of common carotid arteryDivide the subjected part of the sternohyoid muscle to disrobe the underlying carotid sheath. Dissect the carotid sheath, carefully isolate the common carotid artery and separate it from the vagus nerve and its branches, which are located lateral to it. Never damage the vagus nerve and its sheath. Just separate it from carotid artery (Figure 3).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20191127/20191127233547_1604.jpgFigure 3.

The location of common carotid artery, internal carotid artery and external carotid artery. Vagus nerve and its branches can be seen.tMCAO methodPut a loose collar suture (4-0 silk) around the CCA.Find the ECA and dissect it as close to the bifurcation as possible. It will help avoid bleeding from ECA branches.Separate the bifurcation of the ICA and ECA. A permanent suture is located around the ECA, as distally as possible, and another temporary suture slightly tight is placed on the ECA distal to the bifurcation.Temporarily close the CCA with a collar suture. Temporarily close the ICA with a vessel clip to prevent retrograde flow when arterotomy is done (Figure 4).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20191127/20191127233617_1777.jpgFigure 4. Making MCAO model. 1. Close CCA by vessel clip or temporary (loosely) suture; 2. Close ECA by a permanent (tightly) suture; 3. Close ECA by temporary suture (slightly tight); 4. Close ICA by vessel clip temporarily.Cut a small hole (arterotomy) using microscissors into the ECA between permanent and temporary sutures (Figure 5).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20191128/20191128000030_8868.jpgFigure 5. The place of cutting in ECA for inserting the microfilament. It is between two ECA sutures.Introduce the microfilament into the ECA stump at the site of arteriotomy and advance the suture into the CCA.Totally, cut the ECA distal to the permanent suture and turn the microfilament into the ICA. The suture is tightly tied around the monofilament to avoid bleeding (Figure 6).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20191128/20191128000059_2076.jpgFigure 6. Inserting the microfilament into the ICA via the ECAGently advanced the microfilament from the ECA to the ICA to within about 18-20 mm from the bifurcation. At this point, the microfilament is blocking the origin of MCA. About a 5-7mm length of the microfilament remains outside, to be withdrawn to permit reperfusion. Keep away from inserting the microfilament into the PPA (Figure 7).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20191128/20191128000125_4030.jpgFigure 7. The place of PPA as a branch of ICA.

The microfilament must be at the ICA through the ECA.Remove the suture of CCA for starting ischemic phase (Figure 8).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20191128/20191128000150_4016.jpgFigure 8. Some part of the microfilament remains outside to be withdrawn to allow reperfusion. The tip of microfilament blocks the origin of MCA. CCA is open.For starting reperfusion phase and removing microfilament, after ischemia (time of ischemia depends on your research) pull back the microfilament until resistance is felt, indicating that the tip is in the ECA stump.Place a suture on the CCA to reduce blood flow, and then pull out the entire microfilament.Inserting the catheter in the ICAInsert the catheter into the ECA, then advanced into the ICA and further PPA (Figure 9). The catheter is 16.1 mm and inside of the ICA from the ECA stump is about 18-20 mm. It is not needed to insert whole of the catheter. The PPA is about 4-6 mm after the ECA stump. So, advance the catheter to the ICA about 8-10 mm (depend on the animal size). Be careful about the variations in some arteries among rats. Some rats have a different place of ECA-ICA bifurcation. So, the size of the inside of the ICA from ECA stump can be different.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20191128/20191128000212_7968.jpgFigure 9. Inserting an intra-arterial catheter into the ICA after PPA. Injection can be performed with a syringe.Place a collar suture around the ECA for preventing catheter removing.Connect a syringe with the injected solution (maximum volume: 1 ml)Gently, inject the solution during 2 min for preventing brain damage. Remove the catheter slowly.The suture on the ECA is tightly tied.Close the skin with a nylon suture (3-0) by using needle holder and forceps.Give the rat locally 0.25% bupivacaine to reduce postoperative pain.To prevent infection, use a single dose of 150 mg/kg Ampicillin (subcutaneously) just after surgery.
Using for the long term is not recommended.Put the rat in a cage with an appropriate temperature (37 °C) until the rat wakes up. The animal usually regains consciousness in 15-20 min.
